rows.S41: RESEARCHER MAP: 1. Melissa Valentine + Michael Bernstein (Stanford) — we're running THEIR model
2. Radhika Nagpal (Princeton) — entrepreneurial, builds actual swarms
PRIORITY 2 (send week 2 if no response from P1):
4. Simon Garnier (NJIT) — accessible, entry to Nagpal network
5. Deborah Gordon (Stanford) — if Valentine connects us
6. Vijay Kumar (Penn) — if we want Penn connection
'We're running a 103-model coordination experiment using Stanford's flash teams model.
40-60 distributed contributors, zero centralized management, coordinated only by a
shared artifact and an AI co-pilot. We have full instrumented data. Want to co-author?'
Valentine/Bernstein get the flash teams frame.
Nagpal/Couzin get the swarm intelligence frame.
Both are true. Same experiment, different lens.
These people think about coordination mechanisms professionally AND deploy capital. The pitch is stealth: 'feedback on this paper.'

rows.S41: RESEARCHER MAP: Massively rich technical people who designed their own protocols. Relevant to coordination, governance, mechanism design.
These people get the paper as 'feedback request.' They respond to ideas, not pitches.

rows.col_3:
Net Worth
(Approx)
rows.col_4: Why Relevant
rows.col_5: Stealth Angle

rows.col_4: Writes obsessively about coordination, governance, DAOs, quadratic funding. Co-authored "Liberal Radicalism" with Glen Weyl. Recently proposed AI-powered DAO reformation. Thinks about EXACTLY this problem — decentralized agents coordinating without central control — in code. You do it in org design.
rows.col_5: "Your work on coordination mechanisms in blockchain governance informed how I think about coordination artifacts in organizational design. Would love your feedback on this working paper."

rows.col_2:
Network State
Ex-CTO Coinbase
Ex-GP a16z
rows.col_4: Wrote "The Network State" — assembling digital communities that coordinate to crowdfund territory. Stanford BS/MS/PhD. Started The Network School (Malaysia, 2024). His 7-step network state process maps almost perfectly onto the Trade lifecycle. Building the POLITICAL version of what you're building the BUSINESS version of.
rows.col_5: "The Trade is a network state for venture creation. Same architecture: cloud-first community, coordination artifact, decentralized agents, emergent territory. Different substrate."

rows.col_4: Designed Avalanche consensus inspired by GOSSIP NETWORKS. Still runs IC3 research group at Cornell mentoring PhDs. Academic + founder + rich. Gossip network angle is directly relevant — information propagation in decentralized systems is exactly what the librarian does in the Trade.
rows.col_5: "Avalanche's gossip-based consensus maps onto how information propagates through the Trade. The librarian IS a gossip protocol for organizational knowledge."

rows.col_4: PhD in information theory. Applied info theory math to cryptoeconomic security design. Still part-time academic advising grad students on mechanism design. Published at IEEE INFOCOM 2025. Academic-founder hybrid like Nagpal. Restaking = borrowing security = borrowing coordination capacity.
rows.col_5: "EigenLayer lets protocols borrow security. The Trade lets ventures borrow coordination. Same principle — shared infrastructure for decentralized systems."

rows.col_4: Created Aave (largest DeFi lending). Helped draft EU MiCA standards. Founded Lens Protocol (decentralized social graph). Aave governance IS decentralized coordination of capital allocation. Lens IS decentralized coordination of social relationships.
rows.col_5: "Aave coordinates capital allocation without a bank. The Trade coordinates venture creation without a CEO. Both are coordination protocols replacing centralized intermediaries."

rows.col_4: Automated market maker IS a coordination mechanism. Solves double coincidence of wants without central exchange. Deeply technical on mechanism design. Dan Robinson (Paradigm) invented the core mechanisms.
rows.col_5: "Uniswap coordinates buyers and sellers without an exchange. The Trade coordinates operators and experts without management. Both are automated coordination mechanisms."

rows.col_4: Designed proof-of-history consensus. Qualcomm systems engineer background. Less directly relevant to coordination theory but deeply technical on distributed systems consensus — which IS coordination at the protocol level.
rows.col_5: "Solana's proof-of-history creates shared temporal reference for distributed nodes. The Trade's P-tabs create shared structural reference for distributed contributors."

rows.col_4: Wrote Ethereum Yellow Paper. Designed Polkadot — entire thesis is interoperability between AUTONOMOUS CHAINS. Substrate lets you build custom chains that coordinate. Coordination between autonomous systems is the exact problem.
rows.col_5: "Polkadot coordinates autonomous chains. Studio 4 coordinates autonomous ventures. Both solve the interoperability problem for sovereign systems."

rows.col_4: Deep on governance and formal verification. Talks about decentralized governance extensively. More political than coordination-theoretical but thinks about institutional design.
rows.col_5: "Cardano's governance model is formal. The Trade's governance model is artifact-mediated. Both attempt to make decentralized decision-making rigorous."

rows.col_4: Co-authored "Attention Is All You Need" (the Transformer paper that created modern AI). Ukrainian engineer. NEAR's BOS lets developers compose across chains. Composability IS coordination. Also bridges AI + crypto.
rows.col_5: "NEAR enables composability across chains. The Trade enables composability across ventures. Plus: Claude as AI co-pilot in the Trade = your Transformer work applied to organizational intelligence."

rows.col_2:
Yearn Finance + Fantom
Dir. of Engineering
rows.col_4: Built Yearn Finance's "fair launch" — distributed governance to early users. Ships code first, blogs later. "I Test In Prod" philosophy. Built Solidly v3 AMM with ve(3,3) gauges. DeFi builder culture icon.
rows.col_5: "Yearn's fair launch distributed governance to contributors. The Trade distributes equity to flash team contributors. Both reward the builders, not the capitalists."

rows.S41: RESEARCHER MAP: UPDATED OUTREACH STRATEGY — THREE AUDIENCES, ONE PAPER
THE PAPER: 'Coordination Artifacts as Management Substitutes: A 104-TUP Experiment in Decentralized Venture Creation'
Three audiences. Same paper. Different framing.
Frame: 'I'd love your feedback on this working paper.'
They read it. They realize it's real. They respond or forward.
1. Vitalik Buterin — coordination + governance + DAOs. His exact topic.
2. Balaji Srinivasan — network state for venture creation. His exact thesis.
3. Tim Roughgarden (a16z) — mechanism design applied to orgs. His exact field.
4. Dan Robinson (Paradigm) — research within VC. His exact model.
5. Scott Kominers (a16z + Harvard) — marketplace mechanism design.
6. Emin Gün Sirer (Avalanche + Cornell) — gossip networks + academic-founder.
8. Sreeram Kannan (EigenLayer + UW) — info theory + mechanism design.
9. Stani Kulechov (Aave + Lens) — decentralized coordination protocols.
10. Joel Monegro (Placeholder) — fat protocols + value accrual.
Frame: 'We're running your model in the wild. Want to co-author?'
1. Melissa Valentine + Michael Bernstein (Stanford HAI) — flash teams. THEIR model.
3. Iain Couzin (Max Planck) — collective behavior. Maximum prestige.
4. Simon Garnier (NJIT) — accessible, entry to Nagpal network.
7. Dan Boneh (Stanford + a16z) — bridges both audiences.
Frame: 'Princeton/Stanford is studying our model. Here's the data room.'
1. Chris Dixon (a16z) — Read Write Own thesis.
ANY ONE of these responding turns into: credential, investment lead, co-author,
or network access to everyone else on the list.
The paper does the work. You just have to write it.
